cons:

The company is so highly risk adverse that they will allow terrible employees to remain for months or years beyond when they should have been terminated, even at the risk of driving away high-performing employees.
"Face time" is an unwritten expectation despite the work from home flexibility and the drive towards a digital company.  Expectations are often the opposite of what is preached--people are not comfortable providing feedback to their manager or above for fear of retribution no matter how many times Susan Peters tells us to do it.

headline: Great benefits, easy to get lost in the shuffle
pros:
* Great benefits
* Many different businesses and functions to learn about
* Endless opportunities if you align yourself with a power player
* Competitive salary and bonuses
cons:
* Very large company - easy to get lost in the shuffle
* Many GE "lifers" that are often resistant to change and fresh blood
* Inconsistent messaging from leadership
* Constant, frequent senior leadership management changes - big organizational announcements sent via email at least 1-2 days per week
* Oftentimes, the actual responsibilities of the role are much different that what is communicated in the job posting or interview.  Very easy to end up doing tasks just to the get job done.
* Admins are only good at ordering lunches and scheduling travel.  Getting them to do anything with Excel or PowerPoint with a degree of accuracy is out of the question.

headline: Frustration and lack of vision
pros: The pay was above average for our area and the benefits were above average as well.  The location was ideal for those that like fast paced downtown life.  There was always something to do after work which made it a great place to be during spring time/festival season.  Getting involved with community volunteer initiatives was fantastic and rewarding.  (See note in Cons)  Available options to learn with the amount of vendors and "toys" were plentiful.  The people there REALLY tried to make it a great place to work.
cons: Offsite downtown parking could be a nightmare and "the inner circle" were always allowed to park in the building.  Two blocks in the rain can be quite annoying.  Two blocks when it got dark early could also be scary...  The expectation that you would volunteer was unwelcome.  Management from up North didn't help anyone grow their career unless you were "picked" to join the inner circle.  Hearing, "We've always done it this way." is a sure sign the legacy folks like the status quo.  They have lost a tremendous amount of people through the frustration of a missing vision that all can buy into and go attack.  The lack of communication here is a huge bottle neck as well.

The company as a whole does seem to try to make it a better place to work, but some departments get it worse than others.  This company was good to me for the most part, my own personal rating would be a 4, but I know I was an exception, hence the lower rating.
cons: Rigid with scheduling, too many politics resulting in under or unqualified people ending up with promotions, unrealistic and conflicting goals (ie demanding faster call times while adding additional steps required for each call), too much emphasis on having a fast call resulting in reps rushing and making mistakes.  People can be fired for having a couple of bad months, whereas others who take advantage of the system get away with it for years even though management knows they are slacking off.  There are also some awful managers there.  There is a lot to remember and things constantly change and not enough time is given to research during the call nor to train on the new changes, yet a single slip up and management will jump down your throat.

headline: I needed a job and ended up with a career.
pros: Because it is a big company, there are a lot of opportunities for lateral and upward career paths.  The culture is one of integrity and honesty. Additionally, GE Money encouraged professional and personal development and offering many opportunities along those lines.  GE Money also offered opportunities to help in the community.  There were also activities not related to work for those who wanted to engage in fun.  Creativity and forward thinking were always encouraged and welcomed.
cons: Because it is a big company, there were times when some decisions were made up the chain of command with no real awareness of the effects those decisions would have down in the trenches.  Also, there were some pockets of "good ole boy" mentality where popularity won out over professional qualifications.  When dealing with a large number of people, there is bound to be personality conflict or competition and sometimes these things got in the way of good business.  Also, in the small office I worked in, the scheduling for associates was difficult and not employee or family friendly.

headline: Unrealistic Expectations
pros: Nice co-workers; good perks and eventual chances for advancement (I think)
cons: After two weeks of classroom lectures with overheads, we were put on the phones, taking calls.  Some scripting, but federal regs and company policies require certain words be used or not used and in a specific order.. The department records all the calls so they can check them regularly, however, the callers are often hard to hear and understand due to heavy accents. They tell you that this is the week to make mistakes, but if you do, you're history. One warning and the next day, one mistake and you're gone. You might work with people who've been on the job for a few weeks longer than you, however, each person tells you something different.  Even the people assigned to help on the floor give different answers.  You are told to ask for help, but that slows things down. If you don't take enough calls during your shift, you are told that this is unacceptable.  There is no training with mock calls, which would have been the biggest help.  It takes time to get into a rhythm, especially if your background is not in a call center. A little more help and a lot less stress from the manager and I could have become what they were looking for.  Instead, they wasted three awful weeks of my time and theirs.  It seems a pretty inefficient way to run a company.  I wonder if the big bosses out east know what is going on.  UNLESS you have extensive call center phone experience, avoid this one.

cons:
-Extremely sub-par compensation with marginal annual raises, regardless of personal performance, and no bonuses

headline: Be prepared to be a slave to the company  (in FP&A and Controllership)
pros: Nice Offices, Stuctured HR schemes,  Very intelligent people,
cons:
Some of the most unfair working practices I have ever had the displeasure of witnessing.  The hours were long 9-8 most days. During planning sessions 9-11 is common, I have regular stayed beyond that with the company paying for a taxi home (nice of them).
The interns are worked really really really hard.  The FMP's love to be worked hard.  The CAS guys are moved around the globe working unimaginable hours (at least they had the benefit of being able to expense everything). The managers with all the hatred they have built up over the years for giving up their lives love to work everyone else very very hard and the Execs know the business inside out and will have generally been there since they graduated from school.  One exec I knew moved over from the US and stayed in the office every day until midnight.  This is a company of sacrifices and rewards only those that show extreme determination and submission to the company's will.

One strange thing I was aware of is that everyone seemed to have been there for a very long time.  If you look at anyone’s online profile most had a picture there which was of a much younger, slimmer version of themselves. This indicated that most were either very happy with the company or after going through the intern > FMP > CAS route found themselves trapped.  Leaving was not an option for the faint hearted as this would probably mean a significant drop in salary.

I had most of my work experience in various other companies and cannot say that I have ever experienced anything like this.

This was certainly not a place for me !

headline: It depends on the location and local deadership
pros: Diversified businesses and multiple locations open matchless opportunities for people to take diverse roles and live at different places over a period of time. The company even supports this for employees who are at least satisfactory in their performance. Even with periodic layoffs and constant tinkering with organizational structure, GE has the size and finances to provide stable and long-term employment to workers who have average to above average skills and deep perseverance. If the place is not always fair it is not too unfair either. It probably stacks up favorably to more companies than not.
cons: Conformist environment with a weak HR that is more of a mouthpiece of the senior management. Measurement of excellence is not matrixed - contrary to the internal belief. If your style appeals to a senior leader he/she could 'pick' you for bigger jobs. Conversely, no matter how good you are, if you 'do not part hair on the correct side' you would not get any where - the environment encourages quick and constant judgement of people. It is difficult to have a sense of job security with businesses being bought and sold.
